Review title: Surprisingly enjoyable film, headed by two excellent leads!
Review_body: I enjoyed this film, and I do slightly prefer it to the Jodie Foster version. True, the first 15 minutes were a bit slow, and some of the script was a bit weak, not to mention the rather predictable storyline. But you know what, the performances of Lindsey Lohan and Jamie Lee Curtis more than compensated, their performances were really entertaining, and I felt the chemistry between them. I loved the soundtrack, and I thought it was very sensible updating the story, so that it would appeal more to someone like my 13 year old sister, who really enjoyed it. The script, while contrived in some places, was on the whole, very funny, and anyone who's seen the 1976 film, will get a more of the same film, except updated. What I did like, is that Lohan's character is a representation of all of us, someone who doesn't do mornings, doesn't always get on with her mum, and has friends and enemies. In the 1976 version, Jodie Foster's interpretation was more sensible than Lohan's, who put a bit of her other films in, which is quite appealing for this sort of film. Overall, an enjoyable film, with a 7/10. Bethany Cox

Review title: Good work from both actresses in harmless Disney movie
Review_body: Tess Coleman (Jamie Lee Curtis) can't seem to get along with her teenage daughter Anna (Lindsay Lohan). Tess is a therapist getting married to Ryan (Mark Harmon). Anna's life in school isn't going that well. Stacey (Julie Gonzalo) is picking on her. School hunk Jake (Chad Michael Murray) doesn't know she exists. She keeps getting detention. Then Jake talks to her. Her band has an audition but it's her mother's wedding rehearsal. They get into a big fight at the Chinese restaurant and magic fortune cookies set them switching bodies.As a Disney teen movie, it's relatively harmless. It's better than most. Lindsay Lohan is good at playing the teen at this point and it's a good start to her high school roles. It's easier for her to play more uptight during the switch. Jamie Lee Curtis is great at being childish. She has the tougher job. The great thing is that both actresses do credible jobs both before and after the switch. The story isn't that special. It's a pretty straight forward body switch.

Review title: A Delightful Comedy About Respect and Tolerance
Review_body: Dr. Tess Coleman (Jamie Lee Curtis) is a stressed and busy widow psychiatrist, who is close to her marriage with her fiancé Ryan (Mark Hammon). She has a fifteen years old daughter, Anna Coleman (Lindsay Lohan), and a son, the boy Harry Coleman (Ryan Malgarini). Tess and her teenager daughter have problems in their relationship and they do not understand each other. Anna plays guitar in a garage band and is very informal, while her mother hates rock-and-roll and is very conservative. In a Thursday's noon, the family goes to a Chinese restaurant for lunching, and Tess and Anna have a serious altercation. The old Chinese lady (Lucille Soong), owner of the restaurant, gives them two Chinese fortune cookies with the same message. At midnight, their souls change bodies, and when they wake up on Friday's morning, they have to pretend being the other, and they begin to understand each other's problems. This movie was a great surprise for me. I thought it would be another imbecile teenager movie, because of the Brazilian title. When I saw IMDb User Rating, I decided to take a chance and see "Freaky Friday". I found a delightful tale of respect and tolerance, with a great moral in the end, and I loved it. I laughed a lot with the funny situations, and in the end I felt myself lighten. Jamie Lee Curtis certainly is one of the best comedians in Hollywood and is perfect in the role of Dr. Tess Coleman. I was also very impressed with the beauty of Lindsay Lohan, the gorgeous actress who plays the twin sisters in "Parent Trap". The chemistry between Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan is amazing. The soundtrack is spectacular, beginning with "The Turtles", and ending with a great rock sang by Lindsay Lohan herself. This feel-good family entertainment movie is highly recommended for any audience. My vote is eight.Title (Brazil): " Sexta-Feira Muito Louca" ("Very Crazy Friday")

I had heard about this quite a bit, plus I hadn't seen the leading older female star in a film for a while, oh, and it's a remake of a Jodie Foster film. Basically Tess Coleman (Golden Globe nominated Jamie Lee Curtis) and her 15-year-old daughter Anna (Lindsay Lohan) do not get along, and do not have the same tastes in many things (e.g. clothes, music, and especially men). One night though this changes when they go to a Chinese restaurant and get identical fortune cookies, I can't remember what they say, but they cause them to swap bodies the next morning. They decide to try to do all the things they think each other do, i.e. Tess (now Anna) going to work, and a bit of shopping, and Anna (vice versa) going to school. But with Tess's wedding coming up, they cannot stay like this and try and find a way to switch back in their own bodies. Also starring Mark Harmon as Ryan, Patch Adams' Harold Gould as Grandpa, Chad Michael Murray as Jake, Stephen Tobolowsky as Mr. Bates, Christina Vidal as Maddie, Ryan Malgarini as Harry Coleman, Haley Hudson as Peg and Rosalind Chao as Pei-Pei. There are a couple of good slapstick and age difference jokes, but the sentimentality can become a little off putting, and for me it is not really something I would watch again. It was number 78 on The 100 Greatest Family Films. Worth watching, at least once!

Review title: More a reboot than a remake
Review_body: Fifteen year old Anna Coleman is convinced that her mother, widowed psychiatrist Dr Tess Coleman, doesn't understand her and to a degree she is right. Her mother believes that her daughter doesn't appreciate how hard adult life is and she is also right. Things come to a head when Anna's band is due to take part in an important audition on the night of her mother's wedding rehearsal. This leads to a confrontation at a Chinese restaurant; seeing them arguing the owner's mother gives each of them a fortune cookie and says something in Chinese. As Anna and her mother read their fortunes they feel an earthquake, which nobody else in the restaurant appears to notice.The next day they are in for a shock; Anna is in her mother's body and her mother is in her body! After getting over the initial shock they must try to live each other's lives. At first they are somewhat horrified at how the other lives but as each sees the other's lives they grow to understand each other more.I watched the original 'Freaky Friday' as a child in the seventies and again a few years ago; having watched this new version I'd say it is a reboot rather than a remake the premise is the same most key details have changed. The most obvious difference is that the daughter is noticeably older here which means that it is also aimed at a slightly older audience. The story is fun and provides plenty of laughs as well as a few potentially cringe inducing moments involving the boy Anna fancies. Lindsay Lohan and Jamie Lee Curtis do great jobs especially when their characters have swapped bodies and each must play somebody of a very different age. The supporting cast is pretty solid too; especially Mark Harmon who plays Tess's fiancé. Overall this fill is a lot of fun without featuring anything that is likely to offend.

The basic plot of "Freaky Friday" (2003) has been done by Hollywood so many times, one would think a studio would be embarrassed to come out with another version. On top of which, this film is a remake of one starring Jody Foster.Switching bodies, an older person suddenly becoming younger - think everything from "Here Comes Mr. Jordan" to Lifetime's "Drop Dead Diva," with "Big," "17 Again," etc. in between.Now here's the funny part - almost all of the manifestations of this basic plot range from good to excellent, and this "Freaky Friday" is no exception. Why? I'm not sure, but this version benefits from good performances from Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan as a mother and daughter who get switched in a Chinese restaurant. Unfortunately, it's on the eve of the widowed mother's wedding rehearsal dinner and a big audition for the daughter's band. They can't be switched back until they reach a mutual understanding of one another - can it be done in time? I think audiences can relate to walking in another's shoes, and in the case of this film and "17 Again," parents understanding what makes their teens tick is something that all parents wish could happen to them. In any event, "Freaky Friday" is a warm story that wrenched tears from me at the end. Highly enjoyable. Again.

Review title: Walk a mile in her shoes.
Review_body: This a remake of the 1976 Jodie Foster vehicle and debatable which is the better. Dr. Tess Coleman(Jamie Lee Curtis)and her 15-year-old daughter, Anna(Lindsay Lohan), don't see eye-to-eye on the usual things like clothes, music and each other's taste in men. The widowed Tess is reluctant to support Anna's musical aspirations and at the same time is not pleased that Anna won't give her fiancé(Mark Harmon) a break. On a Thursday evening, an enchanted Chinese fortune cookie begins to cause some mayhem. Friday morning, Anna and Tess wake up finding themselves inside the other's body. They literally walk in each other's shoes and gain some insight on the other's viewpoint. A lively soundtrack features the likes of: Forty Foot Echo, Lash, Ashlie Simpson and Miss Lohan's "Ultimate".NOTE: Annette Bening was originally set to play Tess Coleman and I personally wish she did.

Review title: Another in a long line of body swap comedies.
Review_body: Freaky Friday is based on the novel of the same name by Mary Rodgers. It stars Lindsay Lohan as Anna Coleman and Jamie Lee Curtis as her mother. Constantly bickering and with different ideas on life, their lives are turned upside down when an enchanted Chinese fortune cookie puts them in each others bodies. Support comes from Mark Harmon and Chad Michael Murray and it's directed by Mark Waters.This is the third time this material has been adapted by Disney, with the original coming in 1976, and a television remake airing for ABC in 1995. Does Disney think the material is so great that it warrants retreads? Or does the house of mouse feel they have yet to fully do the source justice? Either way, and this version is surprisingly sprightly and accessible fun, it's becoming all a bit too old hat these days. Lohan and Curtis do good work, and the set ups provide enough giggles to stop it from sinking into a mire of unimaginative blandness. While the soundtrack is rocking and certain to appeal to its target audience. But have we advanced from the likes of Big, Vice Versa and the original from 76? Truthly? No we haven't, and we are just left with the feeling that the formula is now used as a cash cow cop out when studios are in need of some box office figures. 5/10

This is about the third adaptation of the Mary Rodgers novel. Finally, the team behind this film has gotten it together. It's obvious the original text has been revised in order to include the language of today. But the best thing about the movie is the casting assembled for it, with a sure director's hand behind it.Actually, this is about the first film that has made me laugh since "Bringing down the house" that came out earlier this year. Most comedies today seem to forget that the basic premise for their existence is to amuse the audiences and entertain them, at the same time.Mark Waters, the director shows he has a fine sense of how to make things move constantly in this comedy about identity changes. Of course, this film wouldn't be half the fun it is without Jamie Lee Curtis, who has never been as effective in any previous films. Her take on Tess Coleman, the not so cool therapist, strikes the right tone.Her daughter is played with a lot of conviction by Lindsay Lohan, who is totally believable as the typical teen ager working through the pain of losing a father and getting a replacement she is not too fond of.Things move at a rapid pace; there is never a dull moment in the film. It's a perfect summer comedy that will leave the viewer satisfied and happy.

Review title: Jamie Lee is the whole show
Review_body: A mother (Jamie Lee Curtis) and her daughter (Lindsay Lohan) are always fighting and screaming at each other.  Each thinks the other has it so easy. Then, through a magic fortune cookie (don't ask), they switch personalities and discover each others problems and complications.Disney remaking another one of its older movies.  I never saw the original so I can't say which one is better.  On its own, this one is pretty OK. It's colorful and pleasant to look at and Lohan plays a teenage girl to perfection. Also Ryan Malgarini is right on target as her annoying little brother.  But the script just isn't there.It's amusing--but that's about it.  It was never hilarious or particularly inspired (all the jokes are pretty predictable).  Lohan was very good acting like she has Curtis' personality in her body...but Curtis steals the show. She plays a teenage girl trapped in a woman's body to perfection--she's very clearly enjoying herself and it rubs off on the audience.  It's just that the script lets her down.  Also Mark Harmon and Harold Gould are pretty bad in their roles.So it's worth seeing for Curtis and some bright, eye-catching photography. Otherwise it's just so-so.  Teenage girls might get a big kick out of it.

This is one of those movies of which you immediately know, from the beginning on, how it's going to end. Still the movies is nicely made and the ending is build up well towards the predictable and sappy but yet suitable ending.Basically this is nicely made teenage-no-worries comedy, with a totally ridicules and not even original story but with a warm feeling and characters. What makes the movie better than most other movies from the genre is that this movie features Jamie Lee Curtis. She was the highlight of the movie and acts truly superb as teenage girl in a grown-up body. She rightfully received a Golden Globe nomination for her role in this movie. I probably will never become a Lindsay Lohan fan but so be it...she does her job well and acts like a true professional on the job. The movie is filled with some fun other characters that probably are better and more interesting than the two main characters.The movie works well, as a light hearted comedy and has some fun moments in it. It's not really a movie that makes you laugh out loud but it is a movie that makes you feel good and happy.Probably best recommendable if you are a teenage-girl but everyone else should also still be able to appreciate this formulaic but nicely made movie, as I did as well.6/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

I won't spend time rehashing comments in detail.I have one reservation here, namely that the story threads concerning the teacher and the bitchy girl were left open, in that although the problem was solved, the consequences of the "remedial" action which Mom took were never seen.Apart from that, I loved this film. Above everything, it was funny, largely thanks to Jamie Lee Curtis, always credible whether as harassed Mom or teen in unwelcome circumstances. However, the script was pretty good too. And Lindset Lohan showed how good she was before she went off the rails. I do hope this young woman rescues herself, and gives us the career she promised in these early films, and herself the future she deserves.The rest of the cast is pretty good, too.Thankfully, the sentimentality remains well reined in.Give yourself a treat and a laugh, and watch this.

Greetings again from the darkness.  Yes, this movie is just oh so cute and yes Jamie Lee Curtis is getting interviewed on all of the talk shows and yes we are so happy that she now has her life back together and yes we are happy she is content with her 44 year old body, yes, yes, yes!  And yes, this is a sloppy remake that with a little effort could have offered so much more. Lindsay Lohan ("Parent Trap" remake) holds her own, but needs to be careful of her next couple of projects or she will never be taken seriously as an actress.  Ms. Curtis is flat out over the top in almost every scene.  She seems hopped up on whatever it is she is taking these days to be so happy in real life.  Mark Harmon is given nothing to work with other than a few arched eyebrows here and there.  What guy wouldn't have sat her down and said "I am NOT marrying you unless you tell me what is going on"?  Veteran actor Harold Gould receives the cruelest treatment and the old grandpa that we must put up with.  The great Stephen Tobolowsky has a couple of nice moments with venom in his delivery, but is mostly wasted.  Chad Murry ("Dawson's Creek" and "Gilmore Girls") is the high school stud of attention. The scenes between he and Ms. Curtis are almost too painful to watch. Bottom line, a strong director would have demanded some script changes to make this movie relevant to today rather than some 70's schlop remake. Go see "Seabiscuit" and "Pirates of the Caribbean" instead.

Review title: Freaky Leads. Not So Freaky Script.
Review_body: Freaky Friday (2003): Dir: Mark Waters / Cast: Lindsay Lohan, Jamie Lee Curtis, Mark Harmon, Harold Gould, Chad Michael Murray: I am not sure why the emphasis is on Friday since it is the dawn of the weekend. Promising remake faltered by cheap sets and simple plotting. Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan play a mother and daughter duo whose bodies are switched due to a lame fortune cookie mishap. Curtis plays a psychiatrist who just completed a successful book. Lohan plays her rebellious daughter who plays in a band and serves detention often at school. They devour fortune cookies at a Chinese restaurant while in the midst of bickering and they switch bodies. This is totally lame in its earthquake effect. Directed by Mark Waters who had already made the embarrassing Head Over Heels. This is not much of an improvement given the fact that Curtis and Lohan actually pull off convincing portrayal, but they are trapped in a formula driven showcase that is beneath them. Mark Harmon is wasted as Curtis's fiancé, and the women at the Chinese restaurant are lame. Harold Gould makes a wasted appearance as grandpa. Chad Michael Murray plays the boyfriend whom mother disapproves of. Remake that toys with one's speech and habits while also addressing age, responsibility and parental role models. Unfortunately it is a remake that is hardly freaky on any given day. Score: 3 / 10

Freaky Friday, this was such a funny movie, and a huge surprise for 2003. This is actually a new favorite comedy of mine; Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan have such a great chemistry, I was really impressed with, new comer, Lohan's performance. She and Jamie just made this film an absolute blast to watch. I think I loved Jamie more though, she captured the whole essence of being a teenager perfectly, she did not over do it at all. Not to mention she's just an absolute pleasure to watch on screen, she's such a terrific actress, I love her so much. The story was just so perfect to update into today's society where everyone is so busy to even notice each other.Anna is a teenage girl, she's pretty typical, she loves music, is a bit angry with her life, a bit of a drama queen, is annoyed by her little brother, and annoyed with her mother who is constantly on her case. Tess, Anna's mom, is a busy lady with a constant on the move schedule, she and Anna just constantly bump heads with one thing or another. Tess is also getting married again to a man who Anna is not too fond of. One night when Anna asks her mom if she can perform at a concert on the night of the wedding rehearsal, it doesn't go so well and they get into a huge fight. The restaurant owner's mom gives them a fortune cookie and ends up switching bodies. They end up learning that maybe their lives are a little harder than what they really expected it to be.Freaky Friday is a very enjoyable film that I'm very sure you'll have a good time watching. It's a very impressive comedy for any age. My favorite scene was without a doubt when Anna(in Tess's body) goes on TV discussing her latest book and tells the truth about why adults worry so much, not to mention the scene where Tess and Anna discover their bodies are switched. This is just a great remake, it has a great cast, a fun script, and is just all around a good movie, I highly recommend it.8/10

i liked the original Freaky Friday(1976)starring a teenage Jodi Foster and Barbara Harris.i thought it was sweet,touching,and funny.this updated version is also really good.it's much higher energy than the original version.the acting by Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan is superb as they play role reversal,Curtis playing the role of the 15 year old daughter Anna,and Lohan playing th role of her mother Tess,while still in their original bodies.of course Anna and her mother have nothing in common,so living in each other's bodies is a real wakeup call.besides the central premise,the movie is formulaic.still.it's fun watching Lohan and Curtis trying to navigate the other one's life.naturally there's a lesson involved,and mom and daughter finally begin to understand each other.anyway really liked it. 9/10

First off, be warned that the first half hour, which is all set up for what happens later, is pretty bland.  It's not horrible, but I was getting a little restless and wondering if this was going to be worth sitting through. But when the change takes place the movie instantly becomes very, very funny.  Part of this is just because the movie has been waiting for this moment and gets to let loose, but a lot of this is because of an amazing performance by Jamie Lee Curtis, and actress who up until now has never really made an impression on me.  Here she is hilariously funny as a teen trapped in an adults body, giving a loose, charming performance while avoiding the temptation to become caricaturish.  The movie itself is quite funny and well written, and Lohan is okay in a role that probably gives her a lot less to work with.  My first reaction to Lohan, by the way, was, oh, so *that's* who she is, as I keep hearing she's kind of a scandalishious teen getting a lot of press for wearing clothes that don't quite stay on and every time I heard the name I'd say, "who?"  So now I know.

Review title: One of my favorite Disney films ever...just an awesome time!!
Review_body: If I have seen the original Freaky Friday film I don't remember so this is my only referral I have for the film. Since the moment I first saw it I have loved it. It is probably one of my favorite films, especially from Disney. While it's no secret that I've been a sucker for Disney films (especially live action) I think Freaky Friday is something extra special. The film is just a lot of fun from beginning to end with some real emotion, and really terrific characters. The idea of the film is a little over the top so you might expect for it to be a little corny or overdone but it never reaches that point. The two lead actors do such an incredible job at making this believable from two separate sides. Director Mark Waters is quickly becoming one of my favorite directors. He has an incredible way of really bringing out characters and also bringing reality to a story. He seems to have a real handle on real life and just makes you riveted to the story. He does it in this film, Mean Girls, Just Like Heaven and most recently with The Spiderwick Chronicles...simply put he knows how tell a story. Plus Freaky Friday holds it's own as a Disney film because it's cute and fun and completely family friendly.Lindsay Lohan in her starring Disney days plays Anna Coleman, the misunderstood, frustrated and typical teenager. Lohan became a star via Disney films for a reason...you just relate to her and are drawn to her characters. She's very 'girl next door' and she DOES have talent. The amazing Jamie Lee Curtis proves her versatility as Lohan's Mom Tess. As Tess she is the perfect mother type to Lohan's rebellious teenager but she really shines as Mom with Lohan inside her. She does such an amazing job of being the same character that Lohan is before they switch. Lohan also does an equally good job playing Curtis' character. They are truly the shining point of the film and they are awesome. Curtis is well deserving of her Golden Globe nomination for the role but Lohan should have received one as well. Chad Michael Murray is the token 'hot guy' that Lohan's character is infatuated with. He doesn't really do much except look pretty but I will say he has great chemistry with Lohan BUT he also has great chemistry with Curtis...weird but very cool for the purpose of the film. The supporting cast is excellent and all very important to the film including the terrific Mark Harmon, very funny Harold Gould, really terrific Ryan Malgarini, Rosalind Chao, Lucille Soong, and Stephen Tobolowsky.Despite the film having a really strong moral message it's not overly intense. It's so much fun and it's just something you can sit down and laugh and smile and just have a really great time and anyone can watch it and it's the type of movie I could watch again and again making it one of my all time favorites. Pretty impressive for a remake. You definitely need to check this out and watch it with the family because I think it is the ultimate family movie with something for everyone and a really cool message to boot. Definitely huge marks here!! 10/10

Hard to imagine why they felt they need to do it, but this is a remake of a Disney film done in the 70s, and adapted after an seemingly successful book. I admit not to be a fan of the so-called family films, and I am among these who think that Disney should have stayed in the cartoon business. 'Freaky Friday' has nothing special to make me change my mind. The gag of the body exchange between different ages characters was already used several times, and all is much too expected in this film where Jaime Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan exchange their mother and daughter bodies for one long day (for the viewers). The generations conflict is reduced to a boring clichee, and the real comic situations (there are a few) are lost in a too much predictable and moralistic story line. Jodie Foster played the daughter (well, daughter body) in the original film, but Lindsay Lohan is no Jodie Foster and she is quite stiff and boring in this film. Jaime Lee Curtis seems to have most of the fun in the body-of-the-mother role, but the Disney norms prevents her to develop the character in what could have been a juicy performance. The rest of the cast is not above the average TV comedy stuff, and so is the whole movie. 6/10 on my personal scale.

Review title: Might have the edge over the original
Review_body: This remake of Freaky Friday might have the edge over the original. It has more emotional depth and it's less cartoon-y, but it does have an unhealthy obsession with full-length musical numbers. Nevertheless, Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan play well off each other and this is a fun film for the family to enjoy together.

Review title: one of these 3 is not like the other...
Review_body: A funny thing happened on the way to this review.A friend asked me to take a look at The Swap -- this review written in 2016 -- and to be frank it was pretty awful.So I dug up the 1976 version, and also this version, for comparison. and watched them all over again.The results: 1976 version -- has the advantage of being the "original" so you can see the influences. But the casting is odd - Foster never really sells her character -- the script lacks punch and the whole thing runs out of steam quickly.2016 version ("The Swap") -- also a bit odd in that, if Disney is going to keep the franchise going for generations (which is how they do things over there) then why cut back on the budget, especially using lesser known actors and a much weaker writing team?? 2003 version -- this one -- may not be the original technically but it is the original in spirit. This version set the bar and set it high. The casting? To die for. Lohan and Curtis are A-listers and it shows. Unlike the other two, you the viewer do not have to constantly remind yourself that the two stars are playing each other because they are so skilled you know it from their gestures and mannerisms. And the script is a gem. Aside from the entertainment value and the cleverness, there are at least a dozen genuinely funny lines. As in you will laugh out loud ("I look like the Cryptkeeper!).As I said, I am writing this review from the far future, ie, 2016.And at least by that date this is the best of the bunch.

10 August 2003. This is a delightful, fun, funny comedy that brings laughs and tears. I enjoyed this movie, one of the most satisfying comedies this year. The physical pratfalls are to die for. The acting and switching personalities is insightful and emotively connecting. The only weaknesses in this movie comes in the rock band tryout and the overly simplified teen relationship resolution - both scenes didn't really feel real or complete. But overall this movie is a gem for the summer, an above average, intelligent, substantive, hilarious experience well worth the ticket price. Eight stars out of Ten.

The scenario is a true actor's challenge. They have to convincingly play the other character within themselves, so the film rests on their performances. And they definitely do live up to it! It leads to all sorts of comedic moments, character development and understanding. The whole thing with the magical fortune cookie was a bit dumb though.

Review title: Deeply funny in a shallow situation
Review_body: Only Hollywood can invent such a comedy, but what a comedy indeed ! Imagine a mother and a daughter in the trap of some Chinese magic and the mother is the daughter and vice versa till a certain prediction is fulfilled. And the mother-daughter is getting ready for her re-marrying on the following day, and the daughter-mother is to perform in a rock concert and is falling in love for a young high-school junior or so. And, etc.  Imbroglio upon imbroglio. When you get one, like one spaghetto I guess, you never see the end of its multiplication, like with spaghetti I guess again. Funny, light, extremely superficial but definitely entertaining and pervaded with enough empathy not to be turned off or down by the over-sentimental and don't-start-all-that-mess-again ending.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris Dauphine, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne & University Versailles Saint Quentin en Yvelines

There is a certain chemistry between Jamie and Lohan and their clash of generation is rather funny. As Jamie had been also a high grader decades ago (« fog », « Halloween »), this movie is also interesting the evolution of education and it's rather a bad one : clothes, manners, knowledge have become loose ! Actually ; when you see how Lohan dresses to go to school and the kind of music she does, well, it's not very kind, open and charming. I know that teenage means rebellion but emancipation can be light too. However my biggest dislike with this movie lies with its treatment of supernatural. The fact that mother and sister have changed souls and that audience can't discern it visually diminishes the impact. Maybe i am dumb, but every time i saw Jaime inhabited by Lohan's soul, i reacted as if she was Jaime who was still playing (I know it was that actually!). In other words, as I witness always the same body, for me, the person stayed the same. To be clear, as soon as the exchange happened, i would have rather Jaime playing the part of Lohan and vice- versa. This way, the supernatural effect would have been clear and it would have been more funny to see Jaime going to high school with Lohan's look It's all the more logical that the movie cover makes this choice: Jaime dressed as a punk girl and Lohan as a Lady! I'm sure this kind of subjectivity reality has been done before (maybe in « X-files ») and i'm sure it would have benefit greatly to the movie !

Review title: Overall silly but I enjoyed it
Review_body: Ah poor Lindsay Lohan before she lost the plot,she was great in The Parent Trap,Herbie Fully Loaded,even this movie was good so here is my review on Freaky Friday.Lohan plays Anna Coleman a rebellious teenager who likes to rock it out with her mates and their band that's up for a completion,but Anna's overprotective mother Tess(played by Jamie Lee Curtis)doesn't want her to miss out on her engagement party dinner with her new fiancé(played by Mark Harmon who also starred in the 2004 movie Chasing Liberty as Mandy Moore's dad who's a president). But when Anna and Tess receive mysterious fortune cookies from a mysterious Chinese woman the two wake up the next morning in body swap reverse. So now Lindsay Lohan IS Jamie Lee Curtis and vice versa for Curtis' charcther. Now the two must figure out how to change back before Tess' big day ???Overall I found this to be a guilt pleasure of mine,its funny,charming and its a great film to watch with your mates. For what it is i'd say check it out.

Review title: Excellent modernized remake of an old Disney classic.
Review_body: With the HORRID Made for TV remake of Freaky Friday starring (get this) Shelly Long (!?!?), I had believed we had just about seen the end of Disney's Family Films. Let's face it, they lost sight of the target years ago, and even their animations are getting worse and worse, except for a few. The sequels to these animations are about the worst things I've ever seen, of late, with no attention whatsoever to detail, or scenery, background, or character development.When this movie was originally made, it was with Jodie Foster as the daughter, and while it was a fun Disney Family Film, it lacked something. Having been made following the formula of "The Parent Trap," you would think it would have fared better, but honestly, Freaky Friday just was not that kind of movie.In this endeavor, they actually pulled it off. It is difficult being a teenager these days. It is nothing like it was when we were young and in school. There is so much pressure now, whereas before, it was much easier to get through the school years. But it is also more difficult being an adult. Every moment of our time is spent and accounted for, scheduled and planned and even the simplest mishap can throw off the entire day, and thereby affect the next and the next. All this is captured without spoiling the fun of the film.I found Jamie Lee Curtis to be delightful. I have never seen a single portrayal by this consummate actress that I did not enjoy, and this film is no exception. Review_body: Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan shine in this absolutely wild and wacky comedy that will make you laugh and feel good. In my opinion, the way she and Annabelle (Lindsay Lohan) magically exchanged bodies was really creepy. This was because the earth rumbled when it happened. The young Lindsay Lohan and the older Jamie Lee Curtis have so much fun in 'Freaky Friday' that we are able to feel that and kind of have the same amount of fun. Like Lohan's 'Mean Girls' (2004) this film could have gone wrong many times but actually never does. It is funny, sometimes moving and teaches parents and teenagers things that they secretly already know. Of course it does things in an exaggerated way but a comedy needs laughs. That things are not annoyingly exaggerated is a big plus for 'Freaky Friday'.Lohan is Anna, a pretty nice teenage girl in a rockband. Her mother does not seem to understand her, or even listen to her, and she is always in a fight with her brother. She also like a guy named Jake (Chad Michael Murray). Sounds familiar. Jamie Lee Curtis is the mother, Tess, who is a therapist, occasionally tries to analyze her daughter, is about to get married with Ryan (Mar Harmon), three years after her first husband, father of Anna, died. Again, sounds pretty familiar. Anna and Tess get in an argument in a Chinese restaurant and the female owner wants to solve the problem; she gives them both a fortune cookie. The next morning Anna finds herself in Tess's body and vice versa. This can only be solved when they understand each other and act selfless.So now Tess in Anna's body has to go to high school, slowly learning that her daughter never really lied. Anna in Tess's body has to work as a therapist, prepare a wedding and slowly she finds out that her mother has a lot going on but means well with especially her children. Of course we already know they will discover things like this, it is how 'Freaky Friday' handles it that makes this film so much fun. The exaggerated things are not in events they will find themselves in, which a lesser film would probably try, but only in the lessons it wants to give.For example it wants to tell that real beauty is in the inside. The exaggeration is that the Jake character falls in love with Anna, but in the time she is in the body of Tess. This seems a little exaggerated, but the situations that bring Jake and the body of Tess together are not implausible at all. Therefore it is easier to take the 'lesson' situation for granted. Besides, the film is simply funny. Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan play each other perfectly, we never get mixed up, making us smile in almost every scene. When actors have so much fun with characters it is hard not to like the film.

Review title: a remake that got it right.
Review_body: SPOILERS THROUGHOUT: My main gripe with remakes is often they don't follow the original. That's the same thing with turning a book into a movie. Well, luckily not every remake is like that. This new updated Freaky Friday sure isn't and my hat's off to the makers of this fun, well acted, and genuinely good, all ages comedy.Freaky Friday-the new version- is at least almost, and maybe, just maybe, as good as, the original. That is so very rare to find, the movie deserves an above average rating for that alone. It works for a couple of reasons.Number one is the incredible casting of Lohan and Curtis. These two could not have been picked any better. They both give good-very good-performances and really nail their characters. Lindsay Lohan is charming, feisty and believable. Jaime Lee Curtis is utterly flawless, hilarious, touching and just so much fun. Watching Curtis in this role one can really see how talented she is even if you've never seen any of her other films. These two females are clearly having a great time in their respective roles as well and the movie in general succeeds in becoming that rare thing-a movie that's hip for young people while still being able to cross over and be a great family movie as well.There is another reason Freaky Friday works and it's a big one. It works because it FOLLOWS THE ORIGINAL!! That is so important. It doesn't try to be so different by coming up with these complex plot twists that don't make any sense. The movie stays a sweet, classic, all age friendly charmer. It doesn't try to be something it's not, it gives the audience the best of what it is.I throughly enjoyed this very entertaining remake and would very much recommend it, particularly to fans of the original. My vote's a solid 8 of 10.

It was a remake and it delivered big time! Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan are an unstoppably funny team of mother and daughter that have just the right chemistry, the right dose of sarcasm and the right dose of whatever it takes to make you laugh and enjoy this film. No film this cheery and delightful would be complete with the dish! And the dish here is Chad Michael Murray with awesome hair, playing the love interest of Lohan's character.The story is about this mother and daughter who don't seem to appreciate each other's lives, so one Freaky Friday, while having dinner at a Chinese restaurant, they both receive fortune cookies with a weird message in them. The next morning, they wake up to find out that they have switched bodies, whereby the mum's character now has the daughter's thinking and reasoning, while the daughter now had the mother's thoughts and reasoning.The result is a pure riot! A must see for everyone who enjoys watching films that warm the heart and make you laugh.
Freaky Friday is an underrated Disney flick with a surprisingly sharp script and plenty of great laugh-out-loud moments. It's a good time.

I wasn't looking forward to seeing this remake but thankfully the people at Disney updated this version and left out most of the overly silly events that could have ruined this. Story is about Anna Coleman (Lindsay Lohan) who is your regular teenager and has the usual troubles at school and plays guitar in a rock band with her friends but she also has trouble communicating with her mother. Tess (Jamie Lee Curtis) is a psychiatrist and a widow with two kids but she's getting ready to get married again to Ryan (Mark Harmon) but she and her daughter Anna are always at odds with each other. *****SPOILER ALERT*****While at a Chinese restaurant they receive two fortune cookies that after being read switches Tess and Anna so they wake up the next morning in each others bodies. Tess/Anna goes to school and finds out that its not as easy as she remembers and also that young Anna has a crush on an older boy named Jake (Chad Michael Murray) but while this goes on Anna/Tess assumes the role as a psychiatrist and has the opportunity to go shopping with newly found credit cards but she also realizes what kind of a person Ryan really is. The two of them not only start to understand each other but also to respect one another and together they discover that they can in fact be friends.This film is directed by Mark Waters who is a capable filmmaker and one thing that is noticeable in the script is the lack of the usual obnoxious characters that we tend to see and that's a credit to both Waters and Disney. The spirited performances are what makes this remake work and while I admired the spunk and maturity of Lohan it's Curtis who uses her experience to put in the more solid effort. The big part of the fun is watching Lohan superbly mimic an uptight adult while Curtis is equally impressive portraying a troubled teen. While the concept of the film is something that we have all seen many times before this latest effort has a freshness and energy that I just couldn't ignore.

This movie is dumb, cheap-looking, and cheesy with some bad acting and poorly executed character development, but it is somewhat entertaining. I wouldn't recommend watching it, but its not the worst thing that you could sit through.

Really good watch, will watch again, and can recommend.I'm not sure what it is about this movie, but it's just an easy, fun watch. Jamie Lee Curtis is a seasoned actress, and Lindsey Lohan had finally built enough experience to be reliable in this role where she's basically doing an impression of Jamie Lee Curtis being her mom. I'm not a huge fan of either one, but I'm not going to deny their acting "chops" and they bring it here, giving the audience a natural and fun atmosphere to the dilemma.There are several very good improvements on original movie in this: cutting a lot of the thought narrative, adding a medium for the swap magic, having them wake up different instead of insta-switching, and several of the added plot lines really help fill out the world better. A career woman is more interesting to follow than a housewife (not that it's necessarily more important), the romance line(s) in this are surprising and slightly less creepy, and swapping a sports game out for musical show not only allowed for the cross competition between character events, but also allows for some great alt rock music throughout the movie: I'll admit to enjoying a movie more when I can relate to the music better.There are several good supporting actors (big and small), to include the Chinese restaurant family which, I think is a very nice cherry on top of the story. By having the source of the magic be an outside party, I think it helps the complexity of the story without causing confusion.It's a fun watch, give it a go.

The wide generation gap between Tess Coleman and her teenage daughter Anna is more than evident. They simply cannot understand each other's preferences. On a Thursday night they have a big argument in a Chinese restaurant. Both receive a fortune cookie each from the restaurant owner's mother which causes them to switch bodies next day. As they adjust with their new personalities, they begin to understand each other more and eventually it's the mutual self-respect that sorts the things out.Even though this was a really funny film, I found it surprisingly heart felt, probably because I can relate to it. The jokes in the films are really funny, with many that will make you laugh out loud. Some scenes are also dramatic, and will make you cry (or it did for me).It's one of the better movies because this comedy is fresh. Well, Mark Water's look of it is fresh and energetic that makes you want to be a kid again. This is the definition of not only a good comedy, but a great family film.This is an obsessive film to watch, in my opinion (along with others). I've seen it about fifty (exagerrated) times and the movie never gets old or tiring. You have to give props to Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan. Their performances are realistic and fantastic!This is one of the best comedies ever made, if not one of the best movies. Yes, some of the daughter and mother relationship is a bit exaggerated but it was fun watching it. If you would like to see a great family comedy, this is the film for you.

Review title: Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan are Magical Together!
Review_body: I honestly barely remember the 1st movie version but this one is great as Jamie Lee Curtis gives a remarkably good performance. She and Lindsay Lohan are extraordinary and they make this far-fetched fantasy tale of body swapping quite believable. A few people thought that the "fortune-cookie curse" and Asian characters were a bit "stereotypical". As I have said in other reviews before: "It's a fantasy so don't take it too seriously". Yes, this body-switching "gimmick" has been used many times before in several (recent) movies and even in science fiction, such as "Star Trek". Here it also proves to be a powerful fable about cooperation and tolerance between family members. It manages to do all that and still be entertaining too! Very "clean-cut" but it just skirts past the un-nerving possibility that Mom could have had sex while inhabited by her 15-year-old daughter's soul. (It doesn't happen) It also covers the very real truth(s) about cruel "bullying" in high school and biased teachers that treat students unfairly. Both happened to me when I was a "kid". Both Lindsay and Jamie are actually playing the guitar and not faking it! Mark Harmon plays the the fiancé of Jamie. Lindsay is best known for: "Freaky Friday" and "The Parent Trap" remakes, "Herbie Fully Loaded", and "Mean Girls". All of which were made early in her film and music career.

Question: What do James T. Kirk, Dudley Moore, Buffy Summers, George Burns and Dick Dastardly have in common?Answer: They've all spent time in someone else's body.You can probably guess that "Freaky Friday" isn't operating from the most original of premises (especially since this is the third time the House of Mouse has filmed the Mary Rodgers novel), and you can also guess what happens next when you learn the bare bones - mother Tess (Jamie Lee Curtis) and daughter Anna (Lindsay Lohan) both think the other's life is a lot easier than their own, and when circumstances lead them to switch bodies they learn more about each other, etc., etc... so it isn't what happens as how it happens that makes or breaks the movie.Happily, director Mark Waters and writers Heather Hoch and Leslie Dixon have Curtis and Lohan in their corner; the two are so believable as mother and daughter, and vice versa, that they paper over most of the cracks in the storyline and also seem to be having a total ball to boot - especially Curtis - and the fun spills out to the audience. It's all pretty predictable stuff, with few if any surprises, but it's genuinely warm-hearted throughout without overdoing its family messages, and the leads and supporting cast (especially Stephen Tobolowsky as Anna's teacher and Harold Gould as her grandfather) put it over. Even Mark Harmon is at his best since "Reasonable Doubts."With the likes of Simple Plan and Ashlee Simpson on the soundtrack and its contemporary references to the likes of the White Stripes and Wango Tango (a real event, for non-Americans), most of the trappings of "Freaky Friday" 3.0 will be as dated in 2030 as the first movie's do now - it's doubtful that Anna would have been playing guitar in a predominantly female rock band in a Disney movie had this been in the '70s, alas - but that's in the future, this is now; and anyway, it's not supposed to be a historical document. It's supposed to be a family movie that's several cuts above average, and it is; is that really such a bad thing? Plus this is a Disney family movie that at least seems like a MOVIE instead of a big-screen TV show, which is definitely not a bad thing."I look like Stevie Nicks." "Who's he?"

For the third version of a movie, as well as being in the same vein as multiple other body switch movies, you wouldn't expect this one to be as enjoyable as it is. The plot pretty much follows its formula, although it is updated to reflect contemporary experiences. However, this version of Freaky Friday was clever, enjoyable, funny, and sweet at the same time. Lindsay Lohan is perfect as the teenage daughter with boys and garage band music on her mind. Jamie Lee Curtis is absolutely fantastic as the girl's mother, who, amidst all of these trials with her daughter, is preparing to marry Mark Harmon. Mother and daughter are not getting along, and, due to a magical fortune cookie administered in a Chinese restaurant, they wake up on Friday in a much different state. Lots of fun and confusion ensues, like Lohan in her mother's body acting like a teenager on a talk show while promoting her book, trying to promote a romance with the hunk at high school, and coming to her own aide with the right guitar riffs off-stage. Curtis in her daughter's body has its moments too, like when she interacts with her fiancé and son, and when she finds out her daughter's teacher is picking on her because of Curtis. The film concludes with a typical, sentimental, Disney ending. This film is a prime example of actors making old material better and more unique than it is. These body switch movies have been made and remade many times over, but this one looks fresh, and, despite the overused premise, is still very enjoyable and funny. The movie ends in a way that leads us to believe there might be a sequel, but so far there's nothing in the works. *** of 4 stars.

The Freaky Fridays have a classic movie premise. Lindsay's and Jamie Lee's Freaky Friday is maybe not quite the overall impressive technical achievement that Jodie's and Barbara's original is, which is so good and such a kind, easy showing, but this Freaky Friday is actually better in a lot of ways. It's funnier, I think. I like this Freaky Friday even more than I do the original because of Lindsay and Jamie Lee and it being from 2003 and it being a little hipper and a little sexier but the '73 one is like, way better, but, just in like an existential kinda sense. 'It didn't suck' is generally the appraisal I give to a film that I expected to hate, but in reality, didn't exactly like, but didn't feel like committing mass murder after seeing it. 'Freaky Friday', directed by Mark S. Waters is one of those films. I actually happen to be a fan of the original film, but while Lindsey Lohan (the ingénue in this version) can't even compare to the great Jodie Foster, her acting wasn't as terrible as it could have been, and the film was bolstered by a fine acting job by Jamie Lee Curtis as her mother. The whole 'switched identity' thing isn't anything new; in fact, it has been virtually run into the ground, but as light-hearted fare with a decent moral lesson, 'Freaky Friday', while not being fine art by any stretch of the imagination is a passable film. I'm certainly not going to rush to see this film again in the next twenty years, but it was fine for what it was meant to be  a mindless and harmless family comedy.--Shelly

To make Freaky Friday work perfectly; you would have to believe that Jamie Lee Curtis is Lindsay Lohan and Lindsay Lohan is Jamie Lee Curtis. Although at times it seemed that way, at other times, it just seemed like Lohan was trying to be Curtis and Curtis was trying to be Lohan. Any way you look at it, Freaky Friday is a family-friendly film that tries to please everyone, and does. It pleases shallow teen prep girls because of Chad Michael Murray. It pleases teen boys because of Lindsay Lohan. It pleases older men because of a Jamie Lee Curtis thong shot. It pleases older women because of Mark Harmon. It pleases the whole family, being that they already saw Finding Nemo and it's the only other family movie out there.Tess Coleman (Jamie Lee Curtis) (changed from Ellen Andrews from the novel by Mary Rodgers) is a harried psychiatrist who still has time for her family. Anna Colemen (Lohan) (changed from Annabel Andrews) is supposed to be a typical teenager (but is anything but), and has daily fights with her younger brother Harry (Ryan Malgarini) (changed from Ben Andrews). Tess is going to marry Ryan (Harmon), because her husband died three years ago (can't there be a Disney movie with both parents still alive?), of whom Anna doesn't approve. After a fueled feud, Tess and Anna open fortune cookies that switch bodies: Tess is in Anna's body, and vice versa. Whatever will be done?Although most people have praised Curtis for her accurate portrayal of a typical teen (although with the people at my school, what she does is anything but typical), and she should be, Lohan does better at being an adult. If Lohan, a teenager, could be an adult so well, that's rather scary. I thought at most times Lohan was Tess, but Curtis was having too much fun as Anna to really be thought of as great. Instead of acting like Lohan, Curtis just acts like a young kid who just ate too much ice cream.One part of Freaky Friday that I didn't like is how often we were put in an awkward situation. And when they were there, they just didn't seem plausible. All of a sudden, Anna-as-Tess is a guest on a talk show, talks to someone she has a crush on, and watches Tess-as-Anna perform? Not only were they awkward, they were just not believable. On the other hand, Freaky Friday not only has some genuinely funny moments, but is also quite touching at times. Obviously, it was going to be, and Tess and Anna were going to learn to respect each other, considering it was shown in the trailer.One other part I didn't like was how far it strayed from the book. It only focused on Anna-as-Tess (Annabel-as-Ellen), and how she spent her day. Of course, back then she was a housewife, but now she has to be a successful doctor. I do admire it for changing it, unlike others, which is basically watching the book. Overall, Freaky Friday is a likable, pleasant 90-minute diverter. It won't change your life, but you won't be upset you saw it.My rating: 7/10Rated PG for mild thematic elements and some language.

I seen the other movie which was released in 1976, and I found that acceptable. Now, I've seen this one, and honestly think the remake is a lot better. You can tell they're both different movies. They don't look similar at all, and that's a good thing. It's a good thing because it means you can enjoy watching both the movies, and you're not watching the same thing again. I liked Freaky Friday. I liked that it involved Lindsay Lohan who is famous for The Parent Trap. She's a good and popular actress. I seriously think Freaky Friday is one of her other good movies. Let's not forget Jamie Lee Curtis who is famous for the movie called True Lies. She played the character named Tess Coleman who is a mother. Lindsay played the character named Anna Coleman who is the daughter. Anna and Tess don't usually get along. On a Friday, there's a freak accident, and they happen to switch bodies. Now, Anna is Tess, and Tess is Anna. They have no other choice, but to lead each other's lives for the day. They find themselves in each other shoes. That's why it's called Freaky Friday. Can they last the entire day? Will they switch places again? You need to see it to find out. Anna happens to be a musician. She plays the guitar. She's in a band. She goes to school. She has one other brother named Harry Coleman. They have dinner at a Chinese restaurant. Anna and Tess have an argument. They are then given fortune cookies by someone, and they read their fortunes loudly, and then the ground shakes. In the following morning, on Friday, they realised they have switched places. Later, during the day, they go back to the Chinese restaurant, and were told by the person who gave the fortune cookie that if they show respect for each other, everything will go back to normal, and they'll switch places again. I know it's strange, but that's what happens. I like how no one other than them has no 'freakin' or 'freaky' idea that they've switched places. Even if they told others that they switched places, no one would believe them. I guess it must be hard being another person for the day. This is what this movie teaches you. What I don't understand is why the day had to be a Friday, and not any other day like Sunday or Monday. That's something the movie doesn't explain. I found that bit strange, but it didn't matter. It's clearly a movie not to be taken too seriously. Freaky Friday happens to be a comedy movie. It's a good movie for the entire family to see. A family movie. You'll like it. The star of the movie was Lindsay Lohan. I only watched it cause of her. I'm just happy that I don't have to switch places like that. It would've been a pain. That's a relief. I think Freaky Friday which was made in 2003 is better than the Freaky Friday made in 1976. They're different movies with different stories and characters. You don't need to see the old one to see the new one. They can be watched in any order. It's better to watch it on a Friday - just to get the feel. Just kidding! It's a strange title by the way. Freaky Friday is a fun movie. It's a movie you can definitely enjoy watching again as well. Now, I understand what is meant by being in another person's shoes by watching this movie - that's something I've learnt.

Review title: A Family Film WIth A Good Deal of Honest Humor
Review_body: "Family Fun" doesn't need to be completely innocuous or empty-headed, and this comedy is a well-crafted, easy-going, energetic time-bending teen fantasy--that will also appeal to parents, as both generations get in their licks when mother and daughter change identities for an inch of time--long enough for either to learn some worthwhile lessons.Freaky Friday is not a stupid film, nor is it cutting-edge--Curtis and Lohan are obviously having a delightful time, and if you're not looking for consciousness-raising of any significance, you will too! It's pleasant to watch a pro at work with a talented younger performer, and with luck, perhaps Lohan will someday achieve the promise as an adult she shows in this delightful romp.

I feel that I could honestly call this one of the funniest movies I have ever seen. "Freaky Friday" stars Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan as a mother and daughter who end up inside each other's bodies, see what each other's daily life is really like, and switch back through the power of love. It's a simple enough story that's been done, but this film takes advantage it. Lohan and Curtis are both very good at seeming as though they are really inside each other's bodies. Putting them in implausible situations (such as the daughter in the mother's body having to go on live TV) are unexpected scenes that end up bringing big laughs. The ending is the usual, involving the mother and daughter coming to a greater understanding of each other, but this one might actually bring a few tears. Jamie Lee Curtis is hilarious in her imitation of a teenage daughter, and her scenes of trying to adapt to situations at work or at home are some of the funniest in the movie. This is Lindsay Lohan's best film since "The Parent Trap," and both of these films are remakes that actually prove to be better than their originals. It's not absolutely perfect, since some of the material can be a little over-the-top at unnecessary times, but it's still very enjoyable. All ages alike will find something to enjoy here.***1/2 out of ****

Freaky Friday represents the second time that Lindsay Lohan has been in a Disney remake, and bettered the original. Freaky Friday provides no surprises, but for a movie like this, that is a compliment.Lohan stars along side Jamie Lee Curtis as a mother/daughter team that are out of touch with each other. Mom (Tess) is a widowed, workaholic psychiatrist, and the daughter (Anna) is trying to negotiate her way through the tough politics of high school. Tess wants desperately wants Anna to accept her husband-to-be, and Anna feels that mom doesn't care about the band she attempting to get off the ground. Neither appreciates the other's life and Anna is extremely put off by her mother's decision to re-marry so soon after her father's death. After a very public argument in a Chinese restaurant, the two are given a magic fortune cookie which causes them to switch bodies and live each other's lives until they work out their differences.Everything that ensues from this point forward is formulaic and predictable, but that does not take away from the fun. The mother, occupying the daughter's body, feels she can work problems with kids through communication and understanding, while the daughter decides it is time to go on a shopping binge, including a navel piercing.The performances from Curtis and Lohan make this film enjoyable. The comedic timing between the two of them is excellent in particular, the subtle way in which each adopts the others mannerisms and habits into their new body.
As a parent , I found Freaky Friday to be completely acceptable family viewing. No real foul language, no innuendo and completely acceptable dress from the teenage characters. This movie also makes it clear that both the parents and the kids have problems in their lives that the other does not understand.Body Switch movies are an old and tired genre, but still, all studios should take a lesson form this film. It is fun, full of laughs, just a little bit moral and free of objectionable content, yet highly profitable. A few more like this a year would be a welcome change. *** out of ****.

Review title: Fished out of the Disney recycle bin and given a fresh look
Review_body: There are times when one must seriously consider the fact that Disney may have a personal patent on film recycling bins. Studios often remake films and rehash old stale ideas but Disney has taken it to a whole new level. For lack of any fresh ideas, they spin a magical wheel with a list of all their old films, and which ever film the wheel stops on it's Remake City. In 2003, Freaky Friday's number came up for the third time since it's original 1976 inception.  What are the odds?  Then again, since it seems that girls have been given short thrift in the film world of role switching, with guys doing it in films such as Big, Vice-Versa, and Like Father Like Son, that Disney decided it was necessary to enforce its own equal rights amendment. Freaky Friday's title comes from what happens one Friday afternoon, when through a magical spell, working mom Tess Coleman (Jamie Lee Curtis) inhabits her teenage daughter Anna's (Lindsay Lohan)body, while Anna at the same time becomes trapped in Tess's body.  Unlike the original film when the spell occurred simply because they mother and daughter repeated the same phrase (I wish I could be Annabel/Mom), here Tess and Anna are aided by the mischievous mother of a Chinese restaurant owner as the two argue inside the restaurant.  It's a minor point, but it does lend a lot more fun to what takes place.As usual for these types of films, a lot of their success depends on how well the actors involved can convince us that the switcheroo actually took place.  Jamie Lee Curtis is hands down the winner in this regard.  Once she becomes Anna, everything about her spells teenager, from her voice inflection to her body language and facial expressions.  She also has most of the best scenes including a sub plot of how a boy the real Anna liked develops a crush on her, a wonderful scene she has working with one of her patients (as Anna), and a hilarious sequence on a talk show where she is hawking her mother's new book.  Lindsay Lohan does not seem quite as successful as Jodie Foster in the original film.  Although she is straightforward and serious enough as her mother, she never seems to develop the physical mannerisms of an adult.  She does have some fine moments though, especially when she changes Anna's looks and clothes into what every mother would adore, and another great scene where she deals with a teacher who has been unfairly harassing her for personal reasons.What this film also has going for it that the original lacked, is more of a sense of purpose.  The original Freaky Friday was played almost entirely as slapstick comedy.  In this version, both Anna and Tess develop keen insights into each others lives, and how tough it is to deal with the world whether you are fifteen or fifty.  Another thing I liked about this film was that unlike the married home maker Ellen Andrews that Barbra Harris played in the original film, Tess is a widow with a successful career, who becomes engaged to Ryan.  It adds some very nice human elements to the plot that were sadly lacking back in 1976.Freaky Friday is an enjoyable farce, that many young teenage girls and their mothers can readily relate to.  Teenage boys may not find much to relate to in it, but they will still enjoy watching it for its off the wall goofy story.  Just don't ask any of those teenage boys to admit they liked it though, because that's something you'll never get out of them.  Being a guy and although my teenage days are long gone, I can admit I did like Freaky Friday, and if a film can get me to admit that it gets my grade, which for Freaky Friday is a B.

'Freaky Friday', other than having one preposterous can't-get-past-it flaw, is a fairly enjoyable film. Compared to most teenage angst flicks (and what could be more horrifying to a teenager than being a grown-up?) we have a veritable winner, actually. Terrific acting, some great lines, good looking stars, decent music, what's not to like? Well, let's talk about that flaw.Any movie operating under the premise of magic is tainted, nay contemptuous. This is the cop-out of the artist, be it writing or celluloid. The message: we can think of no other way to get ourselves out of the corner we've been painted into, so let's contrive a trick to change the situation. So the 'Lord of the Rings' malarkey and Harry Potter connections are guilty by association, and cannot be great films. Magic is boring. You've never seen it and neither have we; imagination requires the use of tangible, or at least scientifically reasonable, platforms for all that has been and will be, period. So why is 'Freaky Friday' acceptable? Simply because of the simplicity of the situation; teen/parent conflict is funny in any time and in any place. Restated, we can identify with all elements of this film, current context going a long ways toward grounding us, even allowing some latitude in the how two people are able to swap identities.And that is indeed what happens as Jamie Lee Curtis (as Dr. Tess Coleman) and Lindsay Lohan (as her daughter Anna) have a spell cast upon them in a Chinese restaurant. What ensues is that each must carry out some semblance of normalcy in their, and others, lives. Thus the teenage band member must appear to be just that whereas the professional adult and mother needs to comport herself in kind.The choice of Jamie Lee Curtis is perfect (Annette Benning apparently turned down the role). Curtis has the comedic energy to pull this off. In her own words, 'Clearly I am of the emotional variety of the immature teenage girl versus the adult' And director Mark Waters (credits include 'Head Over Heels' and 'Mean Girls' - more importantly he had a hand in the phenomenal 'Requiem for a Dream') does do a great job of capturing the inherent zaniness of the entire cast. But Lindsay Lohan is the real up-and-comer here.Lohan has had some very successful films, including this one and 'The Parent Trap' (1998), enabling her to land no less than four projects for 2005. 'Fashionistas', 'Gossip Girl', 'Dramarama' and 'Herbie: Fully Loaded' have been announced or are in pre-production. Her winningly pleasant demeanor makes her one to watch; if teen movies must be made, they may as well have the laughs and hipness that should be a requisite of the type. And in this case ticket sales do reflect at least in part overall quality; teens will not flock to films of the genre that are not contemporarily on target - at least not after more than one weekend. Rating: 2-1/2 Stars.

Who would have thought a remake of a family comedy would actually elicit some really nice performances?  In Freaky Friday, the two leads, Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan, shine in the dual roles they play.  At first, the two actresses fit nicely, and somewhat predictably, as the bickering mother and daughter.  The real fun comes when they switch bodies.  Jamie Lee Curtis is absolutely hysterical when she becomes her daughter, and Lindsay Lohan is actually very believable and very likeable as she plays her mom.The story is also very nice as the two slowly learn of the hardships they each face.  The final scenes where they bond and help each other out are quite touching.  Freaky Friday has only a few minor drawbacks.  The little brother was stereotypically annoying, but there's a nice scene featuring him later in the movie.  I also kind of doubt that some of the references made in the movie (The Hives, The White Stripes) will really be remembered years from now.  Also, the gag of the switched bodies seemed to drag on a little long, but I think it was resolved soon enough, and it all wrapped up nicely.I read recently in Entertainment Weekly that Jamie Lee Curtis said she wouldn't be upset if she didn't work in another movie; that Freaky Friday was the perfect movie to end on a high note.  I think I speak with many people, and hopefully the Academy, that we hope this doesn't happen, but I agree that Freaky Friday is a wonderful and touching film that will live on for quite some time.  People from many generations to come will enjoy Ms. Curtis's performance, as well as Lindsay Lohan's performance.  Kudos to all that contributed to this great movie!My IMDb Rating: 9/10.  My Yahoo! Grade: A- (Almost Perfect)

I adore this movie for the simple fact that it's fun, witty and charming without taking itself too seriously, whilst also delivering a heartwarming message on the relationships with our mothers. Firstly, the film was so innocently yet genuinely funny, and had some joyous and witty moments throughout. They always knew when to apply a joke without dragging it on. Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan had a compelling and hilarious dynamic together, portraying that angsty and frustrating mother-daughter relationship that we all know and love. Lindsay yet again melts our hearts with her cheeky yet loveable teen character. It was apparent they had a lot of fun in their roles, so there was never a dull moment. I thought that the film played with the body swapping concept really well, exploring all of the different scenarios of being forced to live someone else's life, thus creating some hilarious and awkward moments of chaos. It was intriguing watching Lindsay having to appear on a talk show and discuss a book she has no clue about, and her mother having to navigate high school, whilst also making the people around her question how uptight and formal she has become. In this respect, the movie never falters from focusing on the mother daughter relationship, as we realise that despite their huge differences in their attitudes and ideas, their love for each other is the ultimate thing. The romance was strangely complex (for a disney movie), as it becomes apparent that Jake only likes Anna for her personality, thus we see him falling in love with her but in her mothers body, so it was incredibly moving to watch. The movie flowed really nicely, giving us an upbeat and refreshing take on the body swap scenario. Overall, a fun and exciting little movie about a mother daughter relationship and the chaos that ensues when they switch bodies. Highly recommend!
